author: S Harpal Singh
text:
Sirpur MLA Koneru Konappa having lunch with students of the Government Junior College in the Koutala mandal of Adilabad district.-- Photo: S. Harpal Singh

Anyone wanting to witness the intrinsic relationship between education and food security in low income and poverty ridden areas should visit the backward Sirpur Assembly constituency in the Adilabad district of Telangana.

Provision of mid-day meals at government junior colleges here for the last 20 days has resulted in improved attendance of students thereby enhancing the scope for them to perform better in exams.

“You do not need to be an expert to know that food security is valuable to poor students to record good educational performance,” observed Sirpur MLA Koneru Konappa, who is the force behind the ‘private’ effort at providing mid-day meals at plus-2 level.

“No student has missed classes in the afternoon session during the fortnight as we have been providing food at their colleges,” he added.

The result of an experiment in providing free meals to students of Government Junior College, Kagaznagar, had actually enthused the MLA to extend the scheme to other colleges in his constituency this year. “We provided mid-day meals for 40 days and the Kagaznagar College recorded 90 per cent passes and one of its students scored 93 per cent in Intermediate II year exam to stand first in the district,” Mr. Konappa recalled. The students are getting a decent meal consisting of quality rice, one curry, dal and a banana.
title: Thanks to mid-day meals, attendance soars in Telangana colleges
